text: Your child has been invited to a slumber party, but in order to go, you need to give them $10 for pizza. What do you do?
Your child doesn't like having the same food all of the time. They've started crying.
option1: Promise that you'll go out to eat this weekend for $25.
option2: Tell them that you simply cannot afford anything else.

text: The power in your neighborhood has gone out and the food in your refridgerator has spoiled.
option1: Go grocery shopping again (costs the same amount as grocery shopping)
option2: Buy off the McDonald's dollar menu for the rest of the week (costs $20)

text: Your coworker, Steve, has forgotten their wallet and can't afford to buy their lunch today. They ask if you can spot them.
option1: Pay for their lunch $10. Steve never pays you back.
option2: Offer to share some of your own lunch. You end up not getting enough to eat and your work performance suffers.

text: It's Thanksgiving, and it's your turn to host the extended family.
option1: Buy the necessary food to host Thanksgiving ($100)
option2: Lie - Say that you've been scheduled to work on Thanksgiving, and can't host this year.

text: Due to your excessive unhealthy eating, you've had an unexpected medical condition. And the doctor strongly recommends a specific diet.
option1: Conform to the diet - costs $60 for the specialized food.
option2: Continue to eat as you have before. You start to feel perpetually weak and uneasy. Your work performance suffers.
